div.sent: To perform religious rites the monks stay in a particular place during the rainy season.
It is known as Varsavasa.
As the Buddha started to admonish His messages first the Bhikkhus did not stay in a particular place during the rainy season.
They used to advise the people traveling to different places.
According to the Buddha's advice they propagate the Dhamma (doctrine) traveling one country to another on foot.
The then India was a vast country.
But the ascetics of the other faiths stayed in particular places during the rainy season.
For this reason the general mass did not like such practice of the monks and used to criticize them.
At that time the Buddha was residing at the Venuvana vicar of Rajagriha.
He came across the criticism on the traveling of the monks.
He then asked all the Bhikkhus and said, Oh Bhikkhus, do I permit you to observe the Varsavasa.
The Bhikkhus then said to the Buddha, Oh lord, when do we observe Varsavasa?
The Buddha said in reply, Do I permit you to observe Varsavasa during the rainy season.
Since then the system of observing Varsavasa started.
The Mahavagga is a part and parcel of the Vinaya Pitaka of the Tripitaka.
Tile Vinaya consists of the rules and regulations to be observed by the Bhikkhus.
Varsavasa is widely described in the Mahavagga.
In the Vinaya, the year is divided into four seasons.
The Bengali months Chaitra, Vaisakha and Jaistha are included in the Summer, Ashar, Sravan and Bhadra are in the Rainy season.
Aswin, Kartik and Agrahayan are in the Autumn and finally Poush, Magh and Falgun are taken in the Winter.
The members of the Bhikkhu Sangha observe the Varsavasa from the full-moon day of Ashar to the full-moon day of Aswin.
During the period the monks, are not allowed to move extensively.
Staying in a particular place they pass their time in studies, teachings, delivering religious sermons and meditation.
For any purpose if they go for a visit anywhere they return before dawn.
The Varsavasa must not be violated without necessity for the Sangha or any other social emergency.
The residence may be left for the service to the Bhikkhus and Bhikkhunis, Samaneras or Samaneries and the sick laities.
The residence may be left for advising the Bhikkhus and Bhikkhunis who have lost their faith in the Buddhasasana (Buddha's doctrine).
If any lay devotee either man or woman offers a new-built monastery to the Sangha, the Bhikkhu may leave the residence.
For this purpose he may leave residence for far of places up to a week.
To look after the sick Bhikkhu or Bhikkhuni, Samanera or Samaneri, the resident Bhikkhu may leave the monastery for a week.
If any suspicion or misbelief arises anywhere the Bhikkhu may go there for its removal.
The Bhikkhu is allowed to go for the religious performance of Parivasa kamma, Ahabana kamma, Pabbajja kamma and Sahaya kamma.
Besides these, if there happens any disturbance of the wild animals, snakes, thieves or decoits the Bhikkhu may leave the residence.
Again if the residence is destroyed by fire, flood water or cyclone, the resident Bhikkhu may leave the place.
Moreover, the Bhikkhu is allowed to leave the vihara if the laities are quarrelling or controversing.
The aforesaid places built by the lay devotees for charity, the Bhikkhus may break the Varsavasa if they are invited.
For causes other than the above, the Varsavasa cannot be violated.
The Bhikkhus, in the early stage observed the Varsavasa under the open sky or in the hole of trees.
The Buddha prohibitted not to do so and advised them again and again to observe the Varsavasa in the proper places.
He further permitted the Bhikkhus to observe it in the places where the laities live around.
Where there is no obstruction of studies and meditation is the better place to observe Varsavasa.
In the Vinaya it is found that Urubela, Rajagriha, Nalanda, Pataliputra, Sravasti, Saket and Ujjayini were the suitable places to observe the Varsavasa.
Among the important Viharas (monasteries), Jetavana, Rajakaram, Amravana, Anjanvana, Balukaram, Venuvana, Ghositaram, Patikaram, Nigrodharam etc. were noteworthy for Varsavasa.
It is thus observed that, the Bhikkhus and Bikkhunis liked to select undisturbed places for Varsavasa.
The Varsavasa begins from the full-moon of Ashar ending in the full-moon of Aswin.
Some important incidents of the Buddha's life took place on the full-moon day of Ashar.
The Buddha as Siddhartha got into His mother's womb and renounced the palace in quest of supreme knowledge.
Soon after His attainment of supreme knowledge He proclaimed Dhammacakka (Wheel of law) in this full-moon, day at Sarnath.
To the Buddhist this is one of the most virtuous days for them.
The Varsavasa starts from this very full-moon for the next three months keeping the observers absorbed in meditation and religious studies.
So the Varsavasa is the proper time of promising for both the Bhikkhus and the lay devotees.
The mind becomes purified by practising meditation and studies.
Pure mind brings happiness in life.
These holy practices help to attain Sotapatti, Sakridagami, Anagami and Arahanthood.
Many of the Bhikkhus attain Arahanthood absorbing themselves into deep meditation enabling to achieve Nibbana.
It is easy to study at home during the rainy season.
In this period the people finish their cultivation.
They can go nowhere.
Traveling in the country is also impossible.
So this is high time for religious studies and discussions.
They get ample time to listen to the religious sermons from the Bhikkhus residing in the respective monasteries.
As the Bhikkhus can go nowhere during Varsavasa, it is right time to listen to the religious discussions from them.
They do not go far off places.
So it is easier for them to explain the Dhamma mindfully.
The earth remains cool during this period.
So this is a high time for studies and meditation.
The full-moon of Aswin is known to us as the Pabarana.
Kathinacivara dana (Yellow robe offering-ceremony) comes just after Varsavasa.
These celebarations are closely related to each other.
Kathinacivara dana cannot be held if any Bhikkhu does not observe Varsavasa in any monastery.
It is an important religious function for the Bhikkhus to observe.
Because, the age of the monk and nuns (Bhikkhus and Bhikkhunis) is counted from the month of Varsavasa observed by them.
The religious ages of the monks and the nuns are counted by the number of Varsavasa observed by them individually.
Besides, it bears many other importance's.
At the time of introducing the new systems, the Buddha brought reformation of the old ones.
Thereafter, the Buddha prohibitted the Bhikkhus to observe Varsavasa in those places.
It was more beneficial to them to observe it in the desolated places absorbing themselves in studies and meditation.
Besides, the resident Bhikkhus could explain the Dhamma on the days of full-moon, the new moon and the eighth days of the lunar fortnight.
The laities could assemble there to listen to the religious sermons explained by the monks.
The lay devotees from all directions often came to the Buddha to meet Him wherever He resided.
He satisfied them explaining His doctrine.
Exactly the devotees attended to listen to the religious sermons from the Bhikkhus wherever they also stayed.
In this way, their spiritual knowledge developed and contented.
The Buddha spent His last Varsavasa at the village of Belur of Vaisali.
The Bhikkhu Sangha observed their Varsavasa at convenient places around Vaisali.
The Buddha was seriously ill during this Varsavasa.
But by virtue of His unparallel wisdom His illness retarded.
Here He desired to meet the Bhikkhu sangha for the last time.
In the mean time He became fully cured by dint of His profound mental power.
During the last Varsavasa He performed meditation to get relief of sufferings caused by illness.
The Buddha said, It keeps my body active when I perform the Nirodha Samadhi.
It means the meditation during Varsavasa reduces the vigorous sufferings from diseases.
The word Uposatha means fasting.
It is customary to perform fasting on the days of every full-moon, New moon and the -eighth day of the lunar fortnight.
To take meals three times a day is a regular habit of the people.
By fasting from time to time, we can realize the necessity of food.
So it seems to all that fasting is the best Performance of Uposatha.
The Buddha had His meals moderately in due time.
He never took excess food He always advised His disciples to have their meals moderately in time.
In the early stage the Buddha took meals at night.
It is found in the Kitagiri sutra of the Mahijjma Nikaya.
In the sutra the Buddha admonished, Oh Bhikkhus, I have given up taking meals at night.
It has reduced my illness and uneasiness.
You too give up having meals at night.
It will reduce your sufferings from sickness and uneasiness bringing peace of mind.
Since then, the system of having meals before twelve O'clock started.
In this way, the lay devotees also began to take their meals before 12 -O clock on the Uposatha days.
Basically though the Uposatha is derived from fasting, it has some other meanings to the Buddhists bearing a great significance.
The days of the New moon, the eighth day of the lunar fortnight and the full-moon are known as the Uposatha days.
Though the lay devotees generally observe the Five Precepts, they observe Eight Precepts on those days too.
Observance of the Five Precepts is the regular duty for the lay devotees.
The lay devotees who observe the Eight Precepts are known as the Uposathikas.
The duties of the observers of the Eight Precepts have been indicated in the Anguttara Nikaya.
The Buddha defined the Eight Precepts as the salvation from all kinds of sufferings.
In fact, the Uposatha does not mean fasting only.
Purification of mind is the real aim of the devotees who observe the Uposatha Silas.
The decay of cravings is possible by purifying the mind with these Eight Precepts.
The ascetic practice aims at salvation from sufferings.
Once the Buddha was staying on the mountain of Gridhrakuta of Rajagriha.
The general people also assembled there to listen to the religious discussions.
King Bimbisara while meditating in desolated place thought of the performances.
He was then the most devoted lay disciple of the Buddha.
I think, it will be helpful to the people if the Bhikkhus assemble in particular places to discuss on religious topics and performances.
Thus the system of Uposatha came into being.
Following the systems the lay Buddhists all over the world observe the Uposatha till date.
On the Uposatha days they practice the Precepts and take part in charity.
The virtues earned by performing the Uposatha are unlimited.
A servant of Anathapindika went to a far off place for cultivation.
On return in the evening he found all the members of the family observe the Uposatha by fasting.
He also took part in performing the Uposatha.
Due to fasting he suffered from severe pain at the dead of night and died.
Pratijagara Uposatha : To observe the Eight Precepts carefully for whole time is called Pratijagara Uposatha.
The Uposathika has to abide by all the rules strictly excepting the sleep at night.
Gopala Uposatha : The Uposatha observer who always thinks over food, poverty and pecuniary distress excluding the religious performance is called Gopala Uposatha.
They pass their days thinking over poverty and distress like a cow-man.
It is a low standard Uposatha.
Nirgrantha Uposatha : Nirgrantha means knotless or nude.
During the Buddhas period there lived some nude mendicants.
They observed a kind of Uposatha known as Nirgrantha Uposatha.
They took the meals partially and refrain themselves from killing the living beings.
Arya Uposatha : Arya means the best.
It is the best type of Uposatha that introduced by the Buddha.
The disciples of the Buddha observe this Uposatha.
While observing this Uposatha the devotees give up all the worldly pleasures.
They engage themselves meditating in the recollection of the Buddha, the Dhamma, the Precepts and the loving kindness to all living beings.
They refrain themselves from killing the animals, stealing and sexual misconduct.
The laities who observe the Uposatha never take ganja, wine, opium, churus, bhang etc.
They are not addicted to smoking, because it is injurious to health.
Drinking wine opposes right thinking.
Intoxication destroys human knowledge and consciousness.
They hardly realize the difference between good and evil.
The Buddha mentioned the addiction to any kind of intoxicants causes a great loss to human beings.
So should we remember this advice of the Buddha.
The Arya Uposathikas give up all kinds of intoxicants.
They always keep themselves away form enjoying dances, songs, music etc. and observe the Precepts with great devotion.
They further give up wearing the garlands, luxury, cosmetics etc.
They never have their meals at night and never sit or lie on high seats or beds.
Because lying on luxurious beds they cannot concentrate their minds in meditation.
It causes a great hindrance in observing the Uposatha in a proper way.
So everybody of us should observe the Arya Uposatha with devotion.
Observing the Uposatha every day from the full-moon of Ashara till the full-moon of Aswin is called Pratihariya Uposatha.
To observe Uposatha every day for a month starting from full-moon of Aswin till the full-moon of Kartika is an interim Pratihariya Uposatha.
To observe any one of the aforesaid Pratihariya Uposatha is virtuous to the observers.
All these are known as Pratihariya Uposatha.
In the Tripitaka it has been explained to bear good results by observing the Uposatha in many ways.
It is said here that the charming moonlight and the sunshine are not as virtuous as the virtues of observing the Uposatha.
The pearls, the gems and the jewels of the earth and the sea are not as significant as the Uposatha bears.
Even the wealth of the deities is not so splendid as it is.
The fragrance of the heaven and the wealth of the earth are perishable.
But the fragrance of Uposatha is permanent, everlasting and ever peaceful.
Indra, the king of heaven of Tavatimsa once said to the deities.
The more you try to earn virtues, the more you have to observe the Pratijagara or Pratiharya Uposathas.
Thus lead your life in the right path.
We know that the deities are not free from sufferings.
They too possess anger, ignorance and hatred.
But they look over the human virtues and vices.
Indra, the king of heaven admires them too.
The compassionate Buddha introduced these Uposatha Silas to us to observe.
So we should observe the Uposatha Silas (Eight Precepts) as properly as possible.
